Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 212, § 4, which grants jurisdiction to the Superior Court over civil actions where the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County Superior Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, §§ 1 & 2, because the negligent acts and injuries alleged herein occurred in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, within Berkshire County, and the Defendant resides there.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 85 provides that every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable injury to others.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff seeks prejudgment interest on any judgment rendered.

*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care extends to conditions on the property that pose a recognizable risk of harm to lawful users of adjacent public ways.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landowner’s duty to lawful visitors on the premises and, specifically, the rule that there is no liability for natural accumulations of snow and ice absent an act that creates an unnatural condition. It does not address, even tangentially, a landowner’s duty with respect to conditions on the property that pose risks to lawful users of adjacent public ways. The discussion is confined to on-premises hazards and visitor status, not adjacent public way users or off-premises effects of property conditions.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825 (.relevant_excerpt: "The duty owed by a property owner to someone lawfully on the owner’s premises is one of reasonable care in the circumstances. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 (1973). In our most recent decision addressing an owner’s duty with regard to snow and ice, we made clear that this duty is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice. Aylward v. McCloskey, 412 Mass. 77, 80 (1992)."

*Schlemmer v. Lowell*, 33 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care extends to conditions on the property that pose a recognizable risk of harm to lawful users of adjacent public ways.
*Schlemmer v. Lowell*, 33 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case deals with a storeowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect patrons on its own premises from foreseeable criminal acts of third parties. It analyzes foreseeability, security measures, and comparative negligence, but does not address duties owed by landowners regarding conditions on their land that create risks to users of adjacent public ways. Because the opinion is confined to on‑premises injuries to a customer and cites Restatement § 344 (business premises liability), it does not support a proposition about adjacent public ways.
*Schlemmer v. Lowell*, 33 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Southland owed a duty to Flood ‘to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional.’ Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., supra at 452, citing Restatement (Second) of Torts § 344 (1964). It is not necessary that Southland have foreseen precisely the manner in which Flood’s injuries were inflicted.”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.raw_text: *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) (landowner liable for failing to correct known hazards)
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to inspect, maintain, and remedy the hazardous condition of the cracked tree branch after receiving notice of its dangerous state.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a landowner’s breach of duty for failing to inspect, maintain, and remedy a hazardous tree branch after notice. Dos Santos involves a different hazard (a trampoline‑pool setup), and the duty discussed is to remedy an open and obvious danger the landowner affirmatively created and maintained, not to inspect or maintain a natural condition like a tree or to act after notice of a cracked branch. While the case does affirm that landowners can be liable for failing to remedy known hazards they create, it does not address inspection or maintenance duties regarding trees or similar conditions, so it does not specifically support the proposition as framed.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’ … ‘While the open and obvious doctrine may relieve the defendant of its duty to warn, the doctrine does not mean that the defendant can maintain its property “in an unreasonably unsafe condition as long as the unsafe condition is open and obvious.”’”

*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.raw_text: *Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) (foreseeable defects impose duty of reasonable care)
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to inspect, maintain, and remedy the hazardous condition of the cracked tree branch after receiving notice of its dangerous state.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant breached a duty by failing to inspect, maintain, and remedy a known hazardous condition (a cracked tree branch). This case involves an allegedly hazardous freight elevator ceiling and the foreseeability of a particular use, not a tree or analogous defect. More importantly, the court holds that, although the defendant had a general duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, on these facts he did not breach that duty because the risk was obvious and the specific accident was not sufficiently foreseeable. Thus, the opinion declines to find a breach of duty under facts where foreseeability was argued, and therefore does not support the claimed proposition of breach after notice of a hazardous tree branch.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (f.raw_text: *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (foreseeability of harm central to negligence duty)
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (f.proposition: Defendant knew or reasonably should have known that a large cracked branch hanging over a public sidewalk created an unreasonable risk of serious bodily harm to passersby.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (f.support_reasoning: The case deals with a homeowner’s duty regarding foreseeability of harm from negligently stored firearms and third‑party criminal acts, not with premises liability for a dangerous tree or physical condition overhanging a public way. While it extensively discusses foreseeability and unreasonable risk, it does so in the context of guns and criminal misuse, not a landowner’s knowledge of a cracked branch over a sidewalk. Therefore it does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition about a large cracked branch creating an unreasonable risk of serious bodily harm to passersby.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (f.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’… A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’”

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp.*, 454 Mass. 3.proposition: The weather conditions on August 12, 2023, were typical for a Massachusetts summer storm and not so extraordinary as to constitute a superseding cause relieving Defendant of liability.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp.*, 454 Mass. 3.support_reasoning: The opinion in Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp. concerns duty, control of patients, and scope of foreseeable risk in a medical negligence context; it does not discuss weather, storms, or superseding causes related to weather events. The case’s proximate cause analysis is about foreseeability of harms from releasing a medicated patient, not about whether particular weather conditions are ordinary or extraordinary. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about August 12, 2023 storm conditions as a non-superseding cause.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp.*, 454 Mass. 3.relevant_excerpt: "The law does not impose liability for all harm factually caused by tortious conduct. Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct." (Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., 454 Mass. 37, 44 (2009).)

*Kirby v. Boylston St. Corp.*, 344 Mass..proposition: The weather conditions on August 12, 2023, were typical for a Massachusetts summer storm and not so extraordinary as to constitute a superseding cause relieving Defendant of liability.
*Kirby v. Boylston St. Corp.*, 344 Mass..case_name: New England Trust Co. v. McAleer
*Kirby v. Boylston St. Corp.*, 344 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Kirby v. Boylston St. Corp. (as quoted) deals exclusively with construction of a testamentary trust, per stirpes vs. per capita distribution, and determination of the closing date of a class of beneficiaries. It does not address tort liability, weather conditions, superseding causes, or Massachusetts summer storms. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the proposition about whether certain weather conditions were extraordinary enough to constitute a superseding cause.
*Kirby v. Boylston St. Corp.*, 344 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “This is a petition by the trustee under the will of Patrick McAleer for instructions as to whom and in what proportions it should distribute the trust fund set up in article Third of the will, and for instructions regarding the manner of distribution of the real estate which comprises part of the trust corpus.”

*Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.*, 248.raw_text: *Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.*, 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (Cardozo, C.J., principle adopted in Massachusetts regarding foreseeability)
*Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.*, 248.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act despite actual notice of the defective tree limb was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.*, 248.case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
*Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.*, 248.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns proximate cause where a defendant has actual notice of a specific defective condition (a tree limb) and fails to act. Palsgraf does not involve a defective condition or actual notice; it addresses duty and foreseeability, holding that there is no negligence toward a plaintiff outside the foreseeable zone of danger. Cardozo expressly treats proximate cause as ‘foreign to the case’ once there is no duty to the particular plaintiff, so this opinion does not support the claimed statement about direct and proximate cause after notice of a defect.
*Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.*, 248.relevant_excerpt: “The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all… In every instance, before negligence can be predicated of a given act, back of the act must be sought and found a duty to the individual complaining… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us.”

*Irwin v. Ware*, 392 Mass. 745 (1984) (p.raw_text: *Irwin v. Ware*, 392 Mass. 745 (1984) (proximate cause in negligence)
*Irwin v. Ware*, 392 Mass. 745 (1984) (p.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act despite actual notice of the defective tree limb was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Irwin v. Ware*, 392 Mass. 745 (1984) (p.support_reasoning: The case involves municipal liability for police failure to remove a drunk driver from the highway, not a landowner’s failure to remedy a defective tree limb. While the opinion does discuss proximate cause in a negligence context and holds that the police officers’ failure to act could be found to have proximately caused plaintiffs’ injuries, it does so in the specific setting of drunk-driving enforcement. It does not address duties concerning defective tree limbs or notice of a physical defect on premises, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Irwin v. Ware*, 392 Mass. 745 (1984) (p.relevant_excerpt: “Similarly, ‘[t]he question of causation is generally one of fact for the jury…. A plaintiff need only show “that there was greater likelihood or probability that the harm complained of was due to causes for which the defendant was responsible than from any other cause.”’ … The injuries suffered by the plaintiffs occurred no more than ten minutes after Fuller had left Officer Power, and it could be found that they were reasonably foreseeable consequences of permitting Fuller to drive away after being stopped.”
